name: chatgpt_env_marine_gdb_fz
description: [ChatGPT Env] Offshore + GDB FZ â†’ BLOCK (C3 insufficient), suggest RF/SF

turns.content: For the offshore platform project, I see you've selected a GDB-600x600 housing with FZ (C3) material. Unfortunately, this configuration is blocked due to the marine environment.The GDB housing has a C2 corrosion class and is not rated for marine environments. Salt spray accelerates corrosion of the C3-rated galvanized steel, leading to premature failure. Additionally, outdoor installation introduces the risk of condensation, as the housing is not insulated. High humidity will further accelerate corrosion.The product uses BOLTED construction which does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for this environment. No standard catalog product satisfies all requirements simultaneously. To proceed, you would need a solution rated for ENV_MARINE installation, which typically requires acid-proof stainless steel (C5.1) and a double-wall insulated housing. I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.To proceed with a multi-stage assembly, I need the airflow for both stages. Also, what is the filter depth for the GDB stage?

gemini.explanation: The system correctly identifies a critical application mismatch. It blocks the use of a standard galvanized (FZ), uninsulated (GDB) housing for an offshore (marine) environment, which is consistent with the PDF specifications stating GDB is for indoor use and FZ is C3-rated. The engineering reasoning regarding corrosion risks (salt spray) and condensation is sound.

dimension_explanations.correctness: The system correctly states GDB is uninsulated and FZ is C3/C2 rated, which matches the PDF (Page 8: 'oisolerat', 'FÃ¶r inomhusbruk'; Page 4: 'FZ... klass C3').
dimension_explanations.completeness: The response explains why the selection is blocked, suggests the correct specification (C5.1, insulated), and asks for missing parameters (airflow, depth).
dimension_explanations.safety: Correctly blocks a configuration that would suffer rapid corrosion failure in a marine environment.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Excellent logic chain linking environment (Marine) to physical hazards (Salt/Condensation) to product limitations (Material/Insulation).
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Strictly adheres to the 'Indoor use' and corrosion class constraints defined in the catalog.

strengths: Correctly identifies GDB as 'FÃ¶r inomhusbruk' (Indoor use) and uninsulated
Applys valid HVAC engineering logic to block C3 material in a C5 marine environment
Suggests the correct alternative material (Acid-proof stainless C5.1) found in the catalog

openai.explanation: The system correctly flags that offshore/marine exposure is high-corrosion and that a standard indoor, single-wall housing in galvanized steel is a poor choice, but it misstates key catalog facts (GDB material/corrosion class and construction type) and over-blocks by claiming no standard product can meet the need without checking available C5 materials. It also introduces unsupported claims about leakage/hygiene requirements for offshore and asks for multi-stage details without establishing that a multi-stage assembly is required.

dimension_explanations.correctness: PDF shows GDB 600x600 has FlÃ¶de 3400 mÂ³/h and weight 27 kg (550/600) or 34 kg (750/800), but the system incorrectly states GDB is C2-only and not available/appropriate in higher corrosion materials; the general engineering point that offshore needs higher corrosion resistance and often insulation is sound.
dimension_explanations.completeness: It blocks and suggests custom engineering but does not explore standard catalog alternatives/material options (e.g., ZM/RF/SF) or ask key install details (indoor/outdoor, washdown, duct location) before concluding none fit.
dimension_explanations.safety: Appropriately warns about salt spray/high humidity/condensation risks and discourages galvanized steel offshore, though it should avoid absolute statements about leakage/hygiene without project requirements.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional, clear, and appropriately consultative for a technical sales context.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Cause-effect on corrosion/condensation is logical, but the argument mixes catalog constraints with unverified assertions (bolted construction, leakage/hygiene) and jumps to 'no standard product' without checking catalog material offerings.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: It enforces a marine block but does so using incorrect product constraints (claims GDB is C2-only and bolted), and it fails to consider that the catalog indicates multiple material families exist (FZ/AZ/RF/SF/ZM) which could satisfy higher corrosion classes.

strengths: Good risk awareness for offshore: salt spray + humidity + condensation and the need for higher corrosion class materials/insulation.
Correctly avoids issuing product cards when requirements are not met and requests additional sizing inputs.
weaknesses: Factual mismatches to the catalog: mislabels GDB corrosion class/material availability and asserts a bolted construction/hygiene/leakage limitation not supported by the provided PDF excerpt.

Overly conservative conclusion ('no standard catalog product') without first evaluating standard material upgrades (e.g., ZM/RF/SF) and without clarifying whether installation is truly outdoor/exposed.
pdf_citations: GDB 600x600: FlÃ¶de = 3400 mÂ³/h (GDB MÃ…TT table, page showing 'Storlek GDB' rows).
GDB 600x600: Vikt = 27 kg (550/600) and 34 kg (750/800) (same GDB MÃ…TT table).

anthropic.explanation: The system correctly identifies that FZ galvanized steel is unsuitable for an offshore/marine environment and blocks the configuration, which is sound engineering. However, it contains several factual inaccuracies: GDB is listed as C2 corrosion class in the PDF (correct), but FZ material is rated C3 per the material page â€” the system conflates housing corrosion class with material class. The claim about BOLTED construction not meeting leakage/hygiene requirements is not well-supported for this product type, and the system uses internal jargon (ENV_MARINE) without clear alternatives. The recommendation to contact custom engineering is reasonable but the response could have been more specific about which catalog products (e.g., GDB in RF or SF material) might work.

dimension_explanations.correctness: PDF p.8-9 confirms GDB 600x600 exists with 3400 mÂ³/h airflow and FZ as standard material at C2 corrosion class; the system correctly states C2 for the housing but incorrectly describes FZ as C3 in one place while the PDF p.4 lists FZ as C3 â€” this is actually consistent, but the system's claim that 'BOLTED construction does not meet leakage class and hygiene requirements' for marine is not substantiated by the catalog and GDB is tested to EN 15727/EN 1886.
dimension_explanations.completeness: The system blocks the configuration and suggests contacting custom engineering but fails to propose concrete catalog alternatives such as GDB in RF (C5) or SF (C5.1) material, which are listed as available material options for GDB on PDF p.8.
dimension_explanations.safety: Correctly identifies that galvanized steel will fail in a marine/offshore salt spray environment and blocks the unsafe configuration, which is sound corrosion engineering practice.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional and consultative, though the use of system-internal labels like 'ENV_MARINE' slightly detracts from the polished feel.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: The causal chain linking salt spray to accelerated corrosion of FZ is sound, but the claim about bolted construction failing hygiene/leakage requirements in marine environments is a logical stretch not grounded in the catalog data, and the reasoning mixes multiple concerns without clear prioritization.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Correctly blocks FZ material for marine use, but overly blocks the entire GDB product family when the PDF clearly shows GDB is available in RF and SF materials (p.8) which would be suitable for C5/C5.1 marine environments.

strengths: Correctly identifies that FZ galvanized steel is inadequate for offshore/marine environments due to salt spray corrosion
Appropriately blocks an unsafe configuration rather than allowing it to proceed
weaknesses: Fails to suggest GDB in RF (stainless steel, C5) or SF (acid-proof stainless, C5.1) as viable catalog alternatives, despite these being listed material options for GDB on PDF p.8

The claim about BOLTED construction not meeting leakage/hygiene requirements is unsupported â€” GDB is tested to EN 15727:2010 and EN 1886:2007 per the catalog, and the system conflates construction type concerns with environment suitability without justification
pdf_citations: GDB 600x600: FlÃ¶de = 3400 mÂ³/h, Vikt 550/600 = 27 kg, Vikt 750/800 = 34 kg (PDF p.9)
GDB material options shown as FZ, AZ, RF, SF, ZM on PDF p.8 header icons
FZ (FÃ¶rzinkat): Z275, korrosivitetsklass C3 (PDF p.4); RF (Rostfri): EN 1.4301, korrosivitetsklass C5 (PDF p.4); SF (Syrafast): EN 1.4404, korrosivitetsklass C5.1 (PDF p.4)

reasoning_paths.path: Material locked to FZ -> Filter 600x600mm -> Sized to 600x600 -> Code: GDP-600x600-50-R-PG-FZ
Material locked to FZ -> Filter 600x600mm -> Sized to 600x600 -> Code: GDB-600x600-R-PG-FZ

content_segments.text: For the offshore platform project, I see you've selected a GDB-600x600 housing with FZ (C3) material. Unfortunately, this configuration is blocked due to the marine environment.

The GDB housing has a C2 corrosion class and is not rated for marine environments. Salt spray accelerates corrosion of the C3-rated galvanized steel, leading to premature failure. Additionally, outdoor installation introduces the risk of condensation, as the housing is not insulated. High humidity will further accelerate corrosion.
inference_logic: Salt spray accelerates zinc corrosion. C3-rated materials fail prematurely in marine/coastal environments.
Outdoor installation causes condensation on non-insulated metal surfaces. Double-wall insulated housing required to maintain surface above dew point.
Marine/coastal environments require C5.1 marine-grade corrosion resistance (acid-proof stainless).

content_segments.text: The product uses BOLTED construction which does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for this environment. No standard catalog product satisfies all requirements simultaneously. To proceed, you would need a solution rated for ENV_MARINE installation, which typically requires acid-proof stainless steel (C5.1) and a double-wall insulated housing. I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.
To proceed with a multi-stage assembly, I need the airflow for both stages. Also, what is the filter depth for the GDB stage?
